div.p: FARIDPUR RAJBARI JAMALPUR SHERPUR TANGAIL MYMENSINGH NETROKONA SUNAMGANJ SYLHET MOUL AVI BAZAR HOBIGONJ KISHOREGONJ GAZIPUR NARSINGDI DHAKA MANIKGONJ N' GONJ BRAHMAN BARIA COMILLA CHANDPUR LAXMI PUR NOAKHALI FENI M A Y A N M A R MEHER PUR BAY OF BENGAL KHAGRA CHHARI RANGAM ATI BANDARBAN COX'S BAZAR INDIA INDIA INDIA SATKHIRA PIROJ PUR BHOLA CHUA DANGA Kutubdia Sandwip Hatiya CHIT TA GONG SADAR Nobo Jatra Ultra-Poor Graduation programme ‚Ä¢ 7-year USAID activity.
Implemented by consortium of NGOs led by WV Bangladesh
‚Ä¢ 21,000 women direct participants in the graduation program
‚Ä¢ Multi-sectoral programming: UPG, iMSD, WASH, DRR, MCHN, gender governance, citizen voice
‚Ä¢ 3 cohorts of women living on less than $1.90 per day
‚Ä¢ Learning and adaptation between cohorts, esp. cohort 3 (modified standard, group, empowerment approach)

div.head: Nobo Jatra interventions examined
div.p: Intervention Activities UPG (all F) ÔÉó Entrepreneurial literacy training-basic literacy/ numeracy, core business skills. IGA training relevant to skills/ context.
ÔÉó Cash transfers of $12 per month for nine months (monthly allowance). Cash grant of $188 for asset development.
ÔÉó Village Saving and Loan Association (VSLA)-savings group with active savings account in formal financial institution.

ÔÉó Intensive coaching, mentoring, and following up during the programme period. iMSD ÔÉó Entrepreneurial literacy training -enterprise development (almost 100% women). ÔÉó Climate smart agriculture -lead farmers manage plots and generate demand. ÔÉó Capacity building for local service providers (LSPs) in the community. Link smallholders to extension services LSPs), etc.
ÔÉó Linkages with lead firms for both crop and livestock services (inputs). ÔÉó Access to water and sanitation facilities, including their infrastructure development.

div.head: Conceptual framing: linking resilience and poverty dynamics
div.p: ‚Ä¢ Resilience capacities: anticipatory, absorptive, adaptive, transformative
‚Ä¢ Poverty dynamics: chronic poverty, impoverishment, sustained escapes from poverty Study hypotheses

Hypothesis 1 ‚Ä¢ Participation in UPG programme with iMSD is associated with absorptive and adaptive resilience capacity development to tackle chronic poverty. Hypothesis 2 ‚Ä¢ Disaster Risk Management (DRM) training and mobilization and access to WASH services contribute to improving absorptive and anticipatory resilience capacities. Hypothesis 3 ‚Ä¢ Social and behavioural change components in WASH and women's gender equality and empowerment can help support sustained escapes from poverty.

div.head: Research design, data collection and analysis plan
div.p: Intervention groups

‚Ä¢Category 1: UPG iMSD as 'control'/ reference group ‚Ä¢Category 2: UPG iMSD DRR; or UPG iMSD WASH (grouped, and examined separately in analysis) ‚Ä¢Category 3: UPG iMSD DRR WASH ‚Ä¢Category 4 (qualitative data only): No intervention Data collection ‚Ä¢Quantitative ‚Ä¢Phone interviews (CAPI) ‚Ä¢Sample frame of participants, stratified random sampling ‚Ä¢1924 women ‚Ä¢Qualitative ‚Ä¢40 life history interviews ‚Ä¢3 FGDs per site ‚Ä¢10 non-site KIIs Analysis ‚Ä¢Qualitative: coding; content analysis; process tracing for sequences, layering; attributions ‚Ä¢Quantitative: data cleaning, regression analysis-outcomes (1-asset wealth, 2-PPI, 3-subjective wellbeing, 4-food insecurity) and pathways ‚Ä¢Mixed methods integration Summary of key findings UPG activities such as coaching, business development training enabled: ‚Ä¢ diversified livelihoods ‚Ä¢ productive or protective livestock rearing ‚Ä¢ stronger market links helping households to escape chronic ultra-poverty Participation in DRR training, receiving information about early warning, access to WASH all key to improving absorptive and anticipatory capacities that prevent impoverishment. Yet challenges remain amidst multi-sectoral sources of risk. Women's independent or joint decision making, engagement in community savings group all associated with increases in selfreported income and sustained poverty escapes. Challenges persist especially around adverse gender norms. Tackling chronic ultrapoverty Preventing impoverishment Sustaining poverty escapes

div.head: Quantitative analysis
div.p: Three regression models were estimated to analyse whether the wellbeing outcomes of respondents (measured through the wealth index), probability of being poor (measured through the PPI) and self-reported income change, varied across the three study groups (UPG+DRR; UPG+WASH; UPG+DRR+WASH) relative to the reference arm (UPG).
In the regression model:

ùë¶ ùëñ is any of the continuous wellbeing outcome variables (probability of poverty, and asset wealth index) for individual ùëñ, and ùëá ùëñ represents the treatment group (thus individual participation in the layered interventions). ùëã ùëñ ‚Ä≤ is a vector of correlates including other socioeconomic and demographic variables, and ùõΩ and ùúÉ are scalars of coefficient to capture the correlation between dependent variables and independent variables. The measurement error is represented by ùúÄ ùëñ . Equation ( 1) is estimated as OLS.

The income change outcome variable was recorded to take values of 1 for a response of income increased and 0 for a response of no change or income decreased. The analysis employed a probit model to examine the relationships and differences, if any, across the study groups. The probit dichotomous model is specified as:

where ùëÉùëü ùúå ùëñ = 1 | ùëã is the probability of a respondent saying that their income had increased or decreased given, or conditional on, a set of variables ùëã. ùêπ is the functional form that is assumed to be a cumulative standard normal distribution.

div.head: Association of Layered intervention with wellbeing
Qualitative data collection
div.p: Three villages of Kaliganj Upazila were selected for the qualitative interviews based on the presence of an adequate number of participants across intervention groups especially in cohorts 1 and 2 to align with the quantitative survey: Bazargram from Kushuliya union, Tarali from Tarali union and Paniya from Moutala Union. In total, the following interviews were conducted, balanced across intervention arm:
‚Ä¢ 12 key informant interviews (KIIs) were conducted, including with World Vision staff, local service providers, Nobo Jatra facilitators, and village agents, along with local knowledgeable people.

‚Ä¢ 9 focus group discussions (FGDs) were conducted: one female, one male, and one knowledgeable person FGD in each of the three villages, with representatives from different age and wealth groups and social classes.

‚Ä¢ 35 life histories interviews were conducted with female Nobo Jatra programme participants and five with female non-participants from study areas with similar socioeconomic and demographic profiles to households in the study sites. Women were chosen because the Nobo Jatra UPG programme participants by design were all women. In all interviews, there was a particular focus on the last five years to allow for overlap with the project period.
Hypothesis 1: Participation in UPG with iMSD is associated with absorptive and adaptive resilience capacity development to tackle chronic poverty.

‚Ä¢ Quant: Positive association (+) of engagement in most UPG/iMSD activities and perceptions that income increased ‚Ä¢ Qual: diversified farming, livestock ladders, VSLA ‚Ä¢ Challenges: absorption, space, mentorship [NJ] kept paying us taka 1000 for nine months. I would use that money to buy some chickens and ducks. I also bought goat(s)‚Ä¶ all of the ducks and chickens died. Then I bought a billy goat and a doe‚Ä¶ the female goat was pregnant. Anyway, the goat died with its unborn kid. Cash transfer I bought [more] goats‚Ä¶ [NJ] brought in a (vet) doctor from Kaliganj‚Ä¶ He would come to the field for vaccinating people's cattle. We were told [how] to feed our goats regularly and build a slightly elevated platform‚Ä¶ if we kept our goats on the ground, they might have caught cold‚Ä¶ I didn't do all that for the first goat I bought. Yes, they had already given us those instructions, but I thought let's see if I can rear a goat my way... But I had learned my lesson.

div.head: Livestock ladders and loss
div.p: We built a proper shed for the goats. We fed the goats well. We medicated the goats. As the goats grew bigger, I sold each‚Ä¶ We spent the money we earned‚Ä¶ on renovating our house.
We were able to pay for our treatment. It helped us provide for our children. My son is in third grade now.

div.head: Consequences of asset development
div.p: Hypothesis 2: DRM training and mobilization and access to WASH services contribute to improving absorptive and anticipatory resilience capacities
‚Ä¢ Access to WASH and DRR services: households better prepared to face a disaster today and in the future (+)
‚Ä¢ DRR preparedness: income increase (+)
‚Ä¢ Improved water source: income decline (-)

'They trained us about food -during cyclone or disasters how to be safe, save dry foods and save houses from destruction. Houses should be tied down to earth, then we have to go to cyclone shelters' (Nusrat, SE)

'The rate of diarrhoea and acidity was high back when there was no plant. Now it is comparatively lower. My brother owns a pharmacy and I have observed that the sales rate of acidity medicine has reduced‚Ä¶ We now understand that water is the source of all the diseases.' (KI, water plant) Hypothesis 2: DRM training and mobilization and access to WASH services contribute to improving absorptive and anticipatory resilience capacities but challenges remain COVID-19 ‚Ä¢ "At the fish market‚Ä¶ they used to pay my husband BDT20-50. But they would also give him some fish, which we could then sell... [During lockdown] they couldn't transport the fish to distant areas‚Ä¶ you couldn't get a good price for your fish at that time. How the price of other things such as oil, grocery items, and spices spiked!" Ill health ‚Ä¢ "I had gotten ill. After that, my husband died‚Ä¶ I worry about how I would provide for my children now. I am overwhelmed with my anxieties‚Ä¶ I can't memorize anything due to all my tensions. I can't sleep at night. I feel dizzy due to lack of sleep and my anxieties‚Ä¶ Don't we have 6 members in the family? But there's not a single person to earn income." Source: Jannat (UPG+WASH, TE) Source: Jasmine (UPG+WASH, TE) Hypothesis 2: DRM training and mobilization and access to WASH services contribute to improving absorptive and anticipatory resilience capacities but challenges remain

We were doing well during the year before the corona outbreak. NJP started its programme, so we received some financial support from them. Thus we got to rear goats, ducks, and chickens. This helped us better our condition...

div.head: NJ intervention and cash transfer
div.p: Things were going well for us as my husband was earning income, and I too was earning some additional income. We both contributed to the family.

div.head: Collaborative incomegeneration
div.p: As the corona outbreak started, our income decreased as my husband couldn't go outside to work. Also, there was no flow of cash either. On top of that, I got pregnant with my son at that time... He had pneumonia too. We couldn't bear all the expenses of our family and thus I sold the goats...

div.head: Covid-19 and livestock sales
div.p: Source: Sadia (UPG+DRR, TE)
Hypothesis 3: Social and behavioural change components in WASH and women's gender equality and empowerment sustain escapes from poverty.
‚Ä¢ Access to WASH and DRR services: women participate in major household decisions (+)
‚Ä¢ Women who participate in making major household decisions: increase in income (+)
‚Ä¢ Membership in savings/credit groups (with perceived ability to rely on group for support) and membership in farmers groups: increase in income (+)

"Since I was a member of the 'village development committee,' I learned to speak out loud. I am also a member of 'city working group' formed by the union parishad‚Ä¶. They taught us about race discrimination. I am from Rishi community. We could not eat or drink from the same place as other Hindu people. They said that we should protest this‚Ä¶ we can take legal help." (Ritu, UPG+DRR+WASH, SE)

Layering with iMSD: training, quality of market and extension services 'They said that we do not have to go from house to house to sell things, rather the wholesaler will come to our house.' 'We had some lacking in our knowledge before about these issues. Nobo Jatra gave us training in Khulna about these and the trainers taught us a great deal. We learned about how to help the Khamari (livestock farmers) to make more profit, and some basic ideas of how to treat the diseases of livestock.'

'For example, it is better to have food and water in separate bowls for cows. It is a simple change that many village people don't know about. This is an example of the kind of things we learn at training and in the end, reaps a notable result.'
Hypothesis 3: Social and behavioural change components in WASH and women's gender equality and empowerment sustain escapes from poverty.
Recommendations/ summary implications H1: UPG+iMSD is associated with absorptive and adaptive resilience capacities to tackle chronic poverty.
‚Ä¢ A best practice for design of poverty eradication programmes is to adopt integrated, inclusive livelihoods strengthening approaches.
‚Ä¢ Nobo Jatra's coaching element is valuable, and can be built through assigned mentors and monitoring (perhaps relying on local mentors to promote sustainability)
H2: DRM+WASH is associated with absorptive and anticipatory resilience capacities to prevent impoverishment.
‚Ä¢ Better targeting of ill health is critical.
‚Ä¢ Further expanding DRM responses to focus on livestock amid flood and cyclones could also prevent other key sources of impoverishment.
H3: SBCC and gender empowerment is associated with sustained escapes from poverty.
‚Ä¢ Activities to strengthen women's economic empowerment would benefit from a negotiated approach to norm change.
‚Ä¢ A variety of factors beyond programme interventions can enable sustained poverty escapes, and could be considered in a systems framing.

figure.figDesc: DRR ÔÉó Youth mobilisation-Risk Reduction Action Plan (RRAP) development, training, orienting local communities. ÔÉó Community mobilization and training/sensitization -household level preparedness. ÔÉó VDC mobilization -DRR activities, links with other groups, oversight of RRAP. ÔÉó Disaster Management Committee training-including appraisal tools beyond NJP. WASH ÔÉó WatSan committees (50% female) -plan, monitor, report on WASH progress. ÔÉó Social and behavior change -messaging on baby WASH, handwashing, safe drinking water, water treatment, waste fecal management, latrine maintenance, exclusive breastfeeding, antenatal care, and nutrition.

figure.figDesc: Figure source: Poverty dynamics from Shepherd et al. (2014), merged with NJP interventions and resilience capacities framing
